overall_score_comment: Like an actual espresso shot: enjoyable in the moment, but you probably shouldn't think too hard about what went into it.
the_roast:
Sabrina really said 'I'm going to make product placement the foundation of my love life' and ran with it. We've got espresso, Nintendo, Mountain Dew, and somehow perfume all in one relationship—this guy's not falling in love, he's being marketed to. When she says 'That's that me espresso,' I'm genuinely concerned she might be describing a caffeine addiction rather than chemistry. Also, 'I Mountain Dew it for ya'? Girl, that's a verb now? I can't tell if she's flirting or pitching a Super Bowl commercial.

The line 'My give-a-fucks are on vacation' is trying so hard to sound cool and unbothered, but then she spends the entire song explaining exactly how bothered she is with making this guy think about her. Pick a lane! You can't be emotionally unavailable AND wrapping him around your finger while brewing his coffee. That's called having a very available Keurig. And can we talk about 'My twisted humor make him laugh so often'? Bestie, if your humor is so twisted, why are all your jokes just caffeine puns?

The 'move it up, down, left, right, oh, switch it up like Nintendo' section sounds like she's either giving dance instructions or accidentally read the Konami code out loud. I respect the commitment to keeping this man awake, though—between the espresso references and the gaming console comparisons, sleep truly isn't an option. When she drops 'Holy shit' in the middle like she just realized her own power, I felt that. Even she's surprised this word salad of brand names somehow worked.

hidden_meanings: Clearly this is a deep meditation on late-stage capitalism, where human connection has been replaced entirely by consumer goods and brand loyalty. When Sabrina says she's 'working late cause I'm a singer,' she's really commenting on the gig economy and how we're all just caffeinated products in the attention marketplace. Or maybe she just really likes coffee. Hard to say.
final_verdict: A fun, fizzy pop song that's about as deep as a demitasse cup, but honestly? Sometimes you just need a shot of something silly. The lyrics might be 90% product placement and questionable verbs, but it's catchy enough that we'll all forgive her for Mountain Dew-ing it.
title: Espresso
